meaning: adjective: of primary importance; fundamental
example: Most cultures consider gambling a cardinal sin and thus have outlawed its practice.

meaning: verb: to search for something persistently
example: Ever the resourceful lexicographer, Fenton was able to ferret out the word origin of highly obscure words.

meaning: adjective: clear and persuasive
example: A cogent argument will change the minds of even the most skeptical audience.

meaning: adjective: describes someone who is brilliant and lively
example: Richard Feynman was renowned for his scintillating lectures—the arcana of quantum physics was made lucid as he wrote animatedly on the chalkboard.

meaning: verb: to pester
example: Badgered by his parents to find a job, the 30-year-old loafer instead joined a gang of itinerant musicians.

meaning: adjective: making a show of being pious; holier-than-thou
example: Even during the quiet sanctity of evening prayer, she held her chin high, a sanctimonious sneer forming on her face as she eyed those who were attending church for the first time.

meaning: noun: intense hostility
example: The governor’s animosity toward his rival was only inflamed when the latter spread false lies regarding the governor’s first term.

meaning: adjective: open and honest
example: The mayor, despite his avuncular face plastered about the city, was hardly aboveboard – some concluded that it was his ingratiating smile that allowed him to engage in corrupt behavior and get away with it.

meaning: noun: an ill-tempered or violent woman
example: Poor Billy was the victim of the virago’s invective—she railed at him for a good 30-minutes about how he is the scum of the earth for speaking loudly on his cellphone in public.

meaning: adjective: marked by disreputable or unfortunate happenings
example: One by one, the presidential candidates dropped out of the race, their respective checkered pasts— from embezzlement to infidelity—sabotaging their campaigns.

meaning: adjective: blissfully happy
example: Often we imagine all monks to wear the beatific smile of the Buddha, but, like any of us, a monk can have a bad day and not look very happy.

meaning: verb: to willfully violate or destroy a sacred place
example: After desecrating the pharaoh's tomb, the archaeologist soon fell victim to a horrible illness.

meaning: adjective: cheerful; optimistic
example: With the prospect of having to learn 3,000 words during the course of the summer, Paul was anything but sanguine.

meaning: adjective: done before someone else can do it
example: Just as Martha was about to take the only cookie left on the table, Noah preemptively swiped it.

meaning: verb: to gradually increase in size or intensity
example: Her enthusiasm for the diva’s new album only waxed with each song; by the end of the album, it was her favorite CD yet.

meaning: adjective: not relevant
example: The judge found the defendant’s comments immaterial to the trial, and summarily dismissed him from the witness stand.

meaning: adverb: in a frenzied or uncontrolled state
example: Wherever the bowl haircut teen-idol went, his legions of screaming fans ran through the streets amok, hoping for a glance at his boyish face.

meaning: verb: to limit (usually modifying the growth of something)
example: Deserted for six months, the property began to look more like a jungle and less like a residence—weeds grew unchecked in the front yard

meaning: adjective: to be wandering; not sticking to a circumscribed path
example: Unlike his peers, who spent their hours studying in the library, Matthew preferred errant walks through the university campus.

meaning: adjective: appropriate, and matches nicely
example: Her dress was becoming and made her look even more beautiful.

meaning: noun: a wild, confusing fight or struggle
example: After enduring daily taunts about my name, I became enraged and pummeled the schoolyard bully and his sycophantic friends in a brutal melee.

meaning: noun: something that speeds up an event
example: Rosa Parks's refusal to give up her bus seat acted as a catalyst for the Civil Rights Movement, setting into motion historic changes for African-Americans.

meaning: adjective: impossible to estimate or figure out
example: According to many lawmakers, the huge variety of factors affecting society make devising an efficient healthcare system an imponderable task.

meaning: noun: greed (one of the seven deadly sins)
example: The Spanish conquistadors were known for their avarice, plundering Incan land and stealing Incan gold.

meaning: noun: extreme tiredness, either mental or physical
example: Upon finishing a 6-hour standardized exam, Dahlia emerged from the testing center overcome by lassitude.

meaning: adjective: warlike; inclined to quarrel
example: Known for their bellicose ways, the Spartans were once the most feared people from Peloponnesus to Persia.

meaning: verb: to strongly urge on; encourage
example: Nelson’s parents exhorted him to study medicine, urging him to choose a respectable profession; intransigent, Nelson left home to become a graffiti artist.

meaning: adjective: two things are fundamentally different
example: With the advent of machines capable of looking inside the brain, fields as disparate as religion and biology have been brought together by scientists trying to understand what happens in the brain when people have a religious experience.

meaning: adjective: eager to fight or argue; verbally combative
example: The comedian told one flat joke after another, and when the audience started booing, he pugnaciously spat back at them, “Hey, you think this is easy – why don’t you buffoons give it a shot?”

meaning: adjective: felt or undergone as if one were taking part in the experience or feelings of another
example: The advent of twitter is a celebrity stalker's dream, as he or she can experience—through hundreds of intimate "tweets"—the vicarious thrill of living the day-to-day life of a famous person.

meaning: adjective: making less guilty or more forgivable
example: The jury was hardly moved by the man’s plea that his loneliness was an extenuating factor in his crime of dognapping a prized pooch.

meaning: noun: an aggressive takeover by a group (usually military); the group that executes such a takeover
example: As dangerous of a threat as North Korea is, some analysts believe that were a junta suddenly to gain power, it could be even more unpredictable and bellicose than the current leadership

meaning: adjective: to be remorseful
example: Though he stole his little sister’s licorice stick with malevolent glee, Chucky soon became contrite when his sister wouldn't stop crying.

meaning: noun: a person who believes in the superiority of their group
example: The chauvinist lives on both sides of the political spectrum, outright shunning anybody whose ideas are not consistent with his own.

meaning: noun: the highest point
example: The Ivy League is considered the apex of the higher education system.

meaning: noun: a hater of mankind
example: Kevin is such a misanthrope that he refused to attend the Christmas party, claiming that everyone's happiness was "fake" and "annoying."

meaning: noun: a lack of something
example: There is a paucity of jobs hiring today that require menial skills, since most such jobs have either been automated or outsourced.

meaning: verb: to confirm or lend support to (usually an idea or claim)
example: Her claim that frog populations were falling precipitously in Central America was corroborated by locals, who reported that many species of frogs had seemingly vanished overnight.

meaning: noun: a confusing mixture or jumble
example: Those in attendance represented a hodgepodge of the city's denizens: chimney sweepers could be seen sitting elbow to elbow with stockbrokers.

meaning: noun: significant and important value
example: Despite the initial hullabaloo, the play was of no great moment in Hampton’s writing career, and within a few years the public quickly forgot his foray into theater arts.

meaning: verb: to suddenly move in a particular direction
example: All alone in the mansion, Henrietta started when she heard a sound.

meaning: adjective: unreasonable; unscrupulous; excessive
example: The lawyer’s demands were so unconscionable that rather than pay an exorbitant sum or submit himself to any other inconveniences, the defendant decided to find a new lawyer.

meaning: adjective: to be in abundance
example: The exam's passage is flush with difficult words, words that you may have learned only yesterday.

meaning: adjective: emaciated; gaunt
example: Some actors take challenging roles in which they have to lose so much weight that they appear cadaverous.

meaning: noun: a small amount (of money)
example: Vinny’s uncle beamed smugly about how he’d offered his nephew fifty dollars for his Harvard tuition; even twice the amount would have been a mere pittance.

meaning: noun: intense hostility
example: The governor’s animosity toward his rival was only inflamed when the latter spread false lies regarding the governor’s first term.

meaning: adjective: completely stocked or furnished with something
example: Only weeks after the hurricane made landfall, the local supermarket shelves were replete with goods, so quick was the disaster relief response.

meaning: noun: the pinnacle or top of a time period or career
example: During the heyday of Prohibition, bootlegging had become such a lucrative business that many who had been opposed to the 18th Amendment began to fear it would be repealed.

meaning: verb: to hold back or limit the flow or growth of something
example: To stem the tide of applications, the prestigious Ivy requires that each applicant score at least 330 on the Revised GRE.

meaning: noun: a large number of something
example: Despite a raft of city ordinances passed by an overzealous council, noise pollution continued unabated in the megalopolis.

meaning: verb: to deceive
example: Many people have been fleeced by Internet scams and never received their money back.
